name: Multiplying by a three digit integer

skills.name: Multiply 3 digit integers by 3 digit integers using long multiplication
Multiply 4 or more digit integers by 3 digit integers using long multiplication

explanations.A: I think you may have forgotten your placeholder zeros for your tens and hundreds places.
explanations.B: You have forgotten to carry the digits over. For example, 6 x 3 = 18, so you write the 8 down and then add the 1 to the total of the next place value column.
explanations.D: I think you may have only used 1 placeholder zero for your hundreds column, but you need to use 2.

explanations.A: I think you may have only used 1 placeholder zero for your hundreds column, but you need to use 2.
explanations.B: I think you may have forgotten your placeholder zeros for your tens and hundreds places.
explanations.C: You have forgotten to carry the digits over. For example, 7 x 4 = 28, so you write the 8 down and then add the 2 to the total of the next place value column.

explanations.A: I think you may have added 0 to 258 instead of multiplying 0 by 258. Think about what happens when you multiply anything by zero.
explanations.C: I think you may have only used 1 placeholder zero for your hundreds column, but you need to use 2.
explanations.D: I think you may have forgotten your placeholder zeros for your tens and hundreds places.

explanations.A: I think you may have forgotten your placeholder zeros for your tens and hundreds places.
explanations.B: I think you may have added 0 to 367 instead of multiplying 0 by 367. Think about what happens when you multiply anything by zero.
explanations.D: I think you may have only used 1 placeholder zero for your hundreds column, but you need to use 2.

explanations.A: You have your digits aligned to the left, but they should be aligned to the right with the ones places stacked, tens stacked, hundreds stacked, and so on.
explanations.B: The place values should be aligned so ones are stacked vertically, tens are stacked vertically, and so on with the larger number on top.
explanations.C: It seems you wrote out place values, but we just focus on stacking place value digits vertically aligned from right to left with the largest number number on top.
explanations.D: It seems you have numbers aligned to the left and stacked with the smallest number on top. We want the numbers stacked vertically with the ones aligned, tens aligned, and so on, with the largest number on top.

explanations.A: The place values should be aligned so ones are stacked vertically, tens are stacked vertically, and so on with the larger number on top.
explanations.B: It seems you have numbers aligned to the left and stacked with the smallest number on top. We want the numbers stacked vertically with the ones aligned, tens aligned, and so on, with the largest number on top.
explanations.C: You have your digits aligned to the left, but they should be aligned to the right with the ones places stacked, tens stacked, hundreds stacked, and so on.
explanations.D: It seems you wrote out place values, but we just focus on stacking place value digits vertically aligned from right to left with the largest number number on top.

explanations.A: I think you may have forgotten your placeholder zeros for your tens and hundreds places.
explanations.B: I think you may have only used 1 placeholder zero for your hundreds column, but you need to use 2.
explanations.C: You have forgotten to carry the digits over. For example, 8 x 4 = 32, so you write the 2 down and then add the 3 to the total of the next place value column.
